svg.text: The automatic annotation from UniProt keyword "Lipid
metabolism" is accurate. LPL1 is definitively involved in
lipid metabolic processes through its phospholipase B
activity. Duplicate with different evidence code is
Same issue as the IDA annotation - the paper demonstrates
phospholipase B activity, not just lysophospholipase. The
mutant phenotype experiments (IMP) support the broader
This foundational study was among the first to identify
LPL1 as a lipid droplet protein through systematic
proteomic analysis of purified lipid particles.
The IBA annotation appears to incorrectly transfer ROG1
function to LPL1. While both are in the same lipase
family, they have diverged substrate specificities. LPL1
acts on phospholipids (PE, PC, PS, PA, PG) not
Selvaraju et al. 2014 tested phospholipids, not
While LPL1 does cleave at the sn-2 position (phospholipase
A2 activity), experimental evidence shows it subsequently
cleaves at sn-1, making it a phospholipase B. The IEA
annotation from EC:3.1.1.4 is technically correct but
While lipid droplets have a phospholipid monolayer that
could be considered a membrane, this general membrane
annotation lacks specificity. The protein is not found at
cellular membranes like plasma membrane or ER membrane in
its functional state, but specifically at lipid droplets.
The annotation is not wrong but uninformative compared to
This annotation accurately reflects LPL1 function in
breaking down phospholipids. The phospholipase B activity
directly contributes to lipid catabolism by hydrolyzing
this term is too general to be informative about LPL1
specific function. It provides no useful information
beyond what more specific annotations already capture.
This is a classic example of an uninformative high-level
term that should be replaced with specific enzymatic
While LPL1 may transiently associate with ER (lipid
droplets originate from ER), the primary functional
localization shown by focused studies is lipid droplets.
This high-throughput data point is not wrong but
represents a minor/transient localization compared to the
The IMP evidence from lpl1Δ mutants showing altered lipid
droplet morphology, changes in phospholipid levels, and
fatty acid accumulation strongly supports this annotation.
LPL1 maintains lipid balance through its phospholipase
demonstrated that yeast Lpl1 exerts phospholipase activity, plays a
Site directed mutagenesis experiments clearly demonstrated that the
lipase motif is vital for the phospholipase activity
Identification and characterization of major lipid particle proteins
The purified Lpl1p showed phospholipase activity with broader
substrate specificity, acting on all glycerophospholipids [note: PE,
PA, PC, PS, PG tested, not monoacylglycerols]
Lpl1 and Rog1p have diverged substrate preferences but analogous
acting on all glycerophospholipids primarily at sn-2 position and
Lpl1 is exclusively localized in the LD [lipid droplet] at the
acetate labeling in the LPL1 overexpressed strains depicted a
decrease in glycerophospholipids and an increase in free fatty acids
The purified Lpl1p showed phospholipase activity
Lpl1 is exclusively localized in the LD at the stationary phase
One library to make them all: streamlining the creation of yeast
libraries via a SWAp-Tag strategy [high-throughput study]
deletion of LPL1 resulted in altered morphology of LDs and was
acetate labeling in the LPL1 overexpressed strains depicted a
decrease in glycerophospholipids and an increase in free fatty acids
